SPARROW

Over 20 million people in the United States are non-english speakers. Because of this, they have trouble finding appointments that support their health insurance, and are afraid to visit doctors due to medical jargon that they can’t understand. In my information architecture course of 5 weeks, we created Sparrow, a healthcare app that allows users to find suitable health insurance plans and allows them to translate medical terms with their health care providers.

Role : UI/UX Design + Content Strategy

Dates : August 2019

Team : Amaya Mali, Paloma Fernandez, Nancy Zhou, Jenny, Shan Prasad


{ document.getElementById( "communitySplashImage" ).style.display = "block"; }} />

Problem Statement

Non-native english speakers need to be able to secure and access health insurance options, and be able to communicate with their providers effectively.

Needfinding

Through interviews with users who didn’t have practice with health insurance as they were either international students in University, didn’t know how to move away from their family plan, had undocumented or non-english speaking family members, we found the following features indispensible to our application

1. A streamlined way for users to sign up for health insurance.
2. Translate medical jargon with proper context, and diagrammatic support for users.
3. Allow users to find affordable health care and keep track of follow up appointments.

User Personas and Storyboards

Needs + Wants : Has chronic back pains and needs to find low cost healthcare. Is a non-native english speaker and wants to be able to translate her conversations.

This storyboard reflects an instance when a non-english speakers' back starts hurting, they’re able to find healthcare in their area, and through Sparrow, they can translate their entire visit with their doctor.

Competitive Analysis

We compared Sparrow across multiple health care apps that are very popular. Sparrow is unique because it streamlines the health insurance process, which is essential for the 3 million California residents who don’t have health insurance. As language barrier is also an important issue, we wanted the ability to translate medical terminologies amongst other things.

Low Fidelity Prototypes



Our initial prototype for UCSD StudyBuddy had two important features

1. A wish list column on the right where users could request any resource that they wanted, and a helpful UCSD student could upload them.
2. A list of all our educational material, alphabetically sorted based on the course name, where users could find more information.

Alternate Designs

{" "} We wanted to maximize user engagement, especially to Upload books, as we relied on the goodwill of users to upload materials and keep the site running. With this need in mind, we designed 2 workflows for user upload.

Design 1 : Followed a TypeForm approach, where a user had to complete one task at a time. We wanted to encourage resources by only asking for one item at a time and complete the task in 6 simple steps.

Design 2 : Followed a more conventional form, wherein we asked the users for all the information at one go. Our motivation behind this design was that by seeing the entire form in one go, users would realise how easy the task was.

User Testing

We asked the user to find any desired textbook within the app and noticed the following patterns:

1. Users were confused by the folder names (E.g. “BIMM 103”).
2. As the folders weren’t listed in alphabetical order, users spent a lot of time locating their ideal folders.
3. When searching for a specific link, users wanted to be able to sort it (based on year, professor etc. ) rather than scrolling through the entire app.

We also asked them to Upload a textbook through each of the aforementioned workflows:

1. The labels were confusing (didn’t know they had to upload a link or folder)
2. Surprisingly, 50% of our users enjoyed Design 1 for Upload (due to it’s clean UI) and the others enjoyed Design 2 (as it was concise).
3. Some users wanted to maintain anonymity while uploading.{" "}
In general, users enjoyed the simple design, found their required materials easily, and understood the workflow behind the app.

Final Product

- Creating a RESTful online server that allows books, uploads and wishes to be stored persistently and accessed by the user. I was really excited to use the MERN stack to develop my database. View the REST API for{" "} resources {" "} (such as books, lecture notes, exam materials and syllabus) and{" "} user requests {" "} (for the books that they need). { document.getElementById( "communitySplashImage" ).style.display = "block"; }} />

- User can view all the resources in our database. We currently have over 200 materials and hope to keep expanding it. This list is sorted based on the subject and updated in real time. { document.getElementById( "communitySplashImage" ).style.display = "block"; }} />
- As it's a peer to peer file sharing platform, we wanted users to help one another and upload their notes! Through our user research, we found that anonymity was important to users. This was also the phase where we went through two versions, and settled on this one. It increased our potential users by 50%.

{ document.getElementById( "communitySplashImage" ).style.display = "block"; }} />
- Lastly, to make our platform robust, we wanted to allow users to request resources. Once they did, their peers could seamlessly upload them to our database and it would be available for all UCSD Students.

Future Work

Due to remote learning, student’s are facing even more challenges accessing resources such as textbooks, lecture notes etc. To create a production app, we intend on implementing the following steps:

1. Search bar that will allow users to quickly access materials.
2. Ability to upload direct files/folders instead of web hosted links
3. Ability to upload multiple links simultaneously.
4. Login profiles for users to be able to track how many resources they’ve submitted.
I believe that these changes will increase user interaction and user traffic to our website, as they'll be able to find and upload resoucrsed quickly.

); } } export default Sparrow;
